history.content:
Just use search. 

Also I feel like the collective groan at having another Piazza to manage (for admin) and to follow (for students) is enough to say no can do.

children.subject: Oh man I wasn't commenting on the major itself, but I would also appreciate it if EE were a legit major instead of a vanity title that CoE CS freshmen use to brag about their high school stats.

2 things, 1, Averal is a king I love your Piazza posts, 2, that sounds odd Helix, because honestly guys like Pister and Sanders could give a @#!$ [don't ban me admins]. It sounds like you're prolly an underclassman who doesn't yet get what's the deeper thinking here, but as an old man senior, I can absolutely tell you after interviewing tons of faculty, there's such depth to what they choose to teach you and why, that whatever your conception of electrical engineering is, I know you're wrong, because electrical engineering is fundamentally about the following:

Simulating systems' performances to get the best data in the shortest amount of time to ensure the most robust performance.

That's it. You can be an electrical engineer if you work for Eric Paulos [peep make.berkeley.edu] and write code all day. You might not be an electrical engineer if you work for Ron Fearing, maybe in EE 192 and see that writing low level C code or FPGA development has a lot to do with IDEs, and the effects of memory and other computation constraints on the algorithms you can use.

Electrical engineering, at a very deep level, and I say this btw as the complete definition of a failure in EECS, is the exact same thing at computer science. The two terms are self reflexive, and deeper still, mathematics is too. The series of numbers we have can be looked at as a binary graph, of either being 0 or not 0 and then a traversal of a path of primes that generate when we need to make a new node/neuron/binary term, and vice-versa. Consider the proofs of CS 70. Imagine you only had negation. Not only could you make a number line based on seeing and not seeing, via the binary example I gave, but you could develop geometry's and calculus' syntax from the insertive paradoxes you could generate that point to real data [i.e. Zeno's paradox resolved by calculus' definition of limits and the interchangeability of integrals to derivatives]. 

So keep it woke. A first-order axiom proof technique is an EE concept...unless you're taking algorithms classes and you see the same patterns over and over again. All engineering convolves to systems design, i.e. how to make things the most robust via the data we can simulate to give us the information we need to update positioning. 

Also, learning how to search for information is the BIG BIG berkeley idea, you'd be surprised by how good at searching for info, and building information systems, you will become in general, which tragically is the point of an EE 16A/B system.

For deeper insight, I would look at EE 219A, a course on the deep nature of simulation [http://potol.eecs.berkeley.edu/classWiki/tiki-index.php?page=EECS219A-Fall-2014]. Deeper still, I'd prolly ask what's your favorite sandwich, and what's the deepest method of updating to how you make a sandwich you can do to make the tastiest sandwich you can in your lifetime, as all life is just a deep cut of some highly dimensional function of reality

Anon Scale, you dropped this: 👑

Proof by counterexample: Classical closed-loop feedback systems (including most analog circuits) are not data-processing systems; they are actually brilliant because they circumvent data-processing. So, the data isn't really the focus, and any simulation used for modeling is really just a tool (just as much as any computer is a tool). The same argument goes for power system design, device physics, etc. 

As for what "electrical engineering" is, I think it's a lot of things (which makes it so fun), including the collection of data and its processing. But I fundamentally disagree that it need be centered around information or computing. My main gripe is that no part of 16AB, the "gateway" to electrical engineering at this school, really focuses too hard on the actual *electricity* in electrical engineering (meaning that it isn't touched on in a useful manner anywhere in the EECS lower divs). Certainly the math is very important, which is also why 20 was a better "math intro" class than 16AB are, at least in terms of the concepts addressed and preparation for 120 (which is *the* EE class imo). As a 105 TA and student myself, it was incredibly clear that 16AB don't teach basic circuit analysis all too well either. I also think, structurally, making students take two classes in series as opposed to two (or even three if you include Math 54, but then 20/40/ Math 54 covers far more content than 16AB do) in parallel is just needlessly stressful. God forbid a 16C is ever introduced. EE machine broke at this school, what can I say?

Be careful with your assumptions.

I'm also senior but I'm not big-brained enough to care about "information". Obviously I understand the point of EE is to transmit information. I was kidding about the EE being a vanity title. Obviously I know our profs here do great research, and I've taught with two of the professors you listed and they're definitely cool people.

I'm just interested in semiconductor physics and want to be able to have a more specific piazza to keep up to date on relevant department news instead of having to wade through thousands of posts and notifications of what to me is garbage. I would subscribe to email notifications on this piazza if it were more relevant.

I've taken a handful of EE grad classes. I actually tried 219A but I dropped it because it wasn't incredibly pertinent to what I wanted to research in. I'm not really looking for a class in numerically solving ODEs and fast matrix methods. I'm more interested in the quantum physics of electronic devices themselves.

All systems are broke. All things are personal simulations, and you hope so dearly to generate the context of what people are talking about and then you die. Even a quantum computer is to deny the reality of mathematics, that there is no deeply verifiable conclusion to nature, just simulations of simulations all the way down.

This is to say, if you want to make quantum devices, you are deeply suggesting you not only do not make quality sandwiches, but that you have never found yourself in a room of people you can faithfully rely on for love and humor. Even if you succeed in your wildest dreams, your ambition cannot get you to what you want, which is again, a tastier sandwich.

By the by, any self-reflexive system of cognition, following the principa that self-reflexive systems are the most resilient to being undermined, ultimately find their root not in the individual cognition of anyone at all, but the powerful hierarchy of who says what is real and unreal. Even unreal numbers are deep expressions of the dimensions generated from a simple perceptive loop of what's real and what's not real. To make real, of course, is to live an absolutely solitary existence that cannot be understood.

Deeper still, for the design mechanisms of Berkeley, every EECS professor agrees that their course is inherently self-defeating. Even hug, denero, hilfinger, etc. you just play to the lowest common denominator you can, do your best in systems design, etc. but there are deep paradoxes in all actions. For example, the practice.eecsxxx.org websites, for xxx being some course, are clearly the best mechanism for teaching, as it rewards the deep function of play, breaking and analysis of the deep cognition of what you are doing. Despite that, the man deeply behind it, Dan Garcia, and others that follow his thinking, cannot make courses that are self-reflexive, encourage you to learn all the material rather than all-or-nothing efforts on exams, etc. Garcia, Hug, et. al. have developed the CS 9 series, which is functionally still less useful than just going online and trying to figure things out, because there is not one thing that is even remotely effective at being a context generating schema, at all. Even in statistics, the concept of the Black Swan, or the deep paradoxes of mathematics as a whole, suggests a powerful dynamic that all of this could go wrong regardless of how deeply engineered you make your world. Whether you die in a 9/11 style terrorist attack, having a vending machine fall on your head because you couldn't reach the peanuts that fell without tipping it, or being struck by a car as you walk to your mother's house, you will die, it will be brutal and senseless, and EECS should thereby be about helping all people get a deeper sense of natural sense, i.e. drive the semantic generation of structure and syntax self-reflexively.

Also there's an EE grad email list-serv, but it's not really too useful for info. Maybe you have identified a good mechanic for development here, because honestly Piazza is so poorly designed it's laughable, and a BerkeleyTime esque site that had student discussion and the ability to generate systems of data to share to other students would be cool. Maybe it could have a cool name, like the face book, and there would be a company and people would be really nice and good and not ruin things...

All things suck, all jokes suck, all systems suck, and you have no hope for how the information will turn out, but you can enjoy my posting skills, and identify that looking too deeply into improving your conditions probably implies that you can't afford to lose everything, and that truly is some broke thinking.
Can we just take a sip every time the word "deep" appears in one of your above posts?

haha can you imagine suggesting that the structure of the EECS curriculum and admission to the undergrad EECS program ensures that EE is an afterthought compared to CS almost exactly three years ago now?? hypothetically, if someone had done that, that would have been crazy! thankfully we live in a utopia where problems don't exist, so such discussions are not necessary
Why can’t we just create an EE tag to make posts easy to sort?

history.content:
It's super tiring as an EECS major interested in device physics to scroll through hundreds of:

"What's the best prep for 189?"

"How do I get research with Abbeel?"

"How hard is Data 100?"

I find it frustrating to sort through hundreds of posts in order to find the few posts that are relevant to me.

Given that CS majors don't want to read posts about device physics and analog design either, would it be possible to make a separate EE 101 and CS 101?
history.subject: Can we split the EECS 101 Piazza into EE and CS 101?
